swift/obj/server.py.message:
We can't just go off of the x-timestamp value?

I guess we have to worry about back-dated work like reconciler data movement... but how busy does that really tend to be?

You guys know that gettimeofday() is not even a syscall on Linux, right? Apps such as desktops and browsers hit it super hard, because they time all events. So, I went and make up a few tests to see if time.time() was any good.

Results were not good. It's basically equivalent to fp.read(1) off an in-memory file, such as "/dev/urandom". And it's the same on py27 and py37 (with py37 being generally slightly faster).

I think now that Tim is right to be concerned, although this is only 1 more call per request. If we added a time.time() per every buffer, I'd add a -1 right away.

Using X-timestamp may be more correct semantically, regardless of the performance.

OK, I see comparable results between the two on my laptop:

 $ python -m timeit -s 'import time' 'time.time()'
 5000000 loops, best of 5: 75 nsec per loop
 $ python -m timeit -s 'x=open("/dev/urandom", "rb")' 'x.read(1)'
 5000000 loops, best of 5: 74.6 nsec per loop

But I feel like we're being penny-wise and pound-foolish by chasing sub-microsecond timings when we're already committed to writing something to disk. Even ignoring the pickling and tempfile renaming, we're talking milliseconds:

 $ python -m timeit -s 'import os; x=open("./test-file", "wb")' \
     'x.write(b"x"); x.flush(); os.fsync(x.fileno())'
 100 loops, best of 5: 3.8 msec per loop

Even in a more resource-constrained environment like my raspberry pi, time.time() is pretty damn cheap:

 pi@tburke-pi:~ $ python -m timeit -s 'import time' 'time.time()'
 1000000 loops, best of 3: 0.824 usec per loop

A decent bit cheaper than reading a random byte, in fact:

 pi@tburke-pi:~ $ python -m timeit -s 'x=open("/dev/urandom", "rb")' 'x.read(1)'
 1000000 loops, best of 3: 1.94 usec per loop

I think the main question ought to be whether the metric is useful and can be understood -- and in that context, the possibility of container-sync being enabled for a container with arbitrarily-old data *already in it* makes a pretty compelling case for using the current time.

swift/obj/updater.py.message:
Would it be better to emit the timing here? It seems a little strange to me that, as written, this emits multiple times per update...

It might also be good to emit for both successes and failures. Otherwise you risk having your metric stay low even as the situation is deteriorating, just because some containers are overloaded and can barely eat *any* updates. I'm guessing we'd want to distinguish them as lag.success and lag.failure.

this could be really big or really small - sometimes days sometimes less than a minute.  Also this metric might be sparse - no data for a while, then 100/s.  Are we going to be able to make sense of that in a time series database?

You're right that, by itself, it may not make much sense. I refrained myself from adding the (account,container) in the serie name because the cardinality would kill most timeseries platform.

It's far from perfect, but at least it can help the operator to notify if there is any issue (eg: watching the 90percentile or something like that)
Yeah, I'm not *so* worried about it -- seems roughly on par with our proxy-server timings.

playbooks/pre-integration.yaml.message: We now have an omnitruck instance up, so you can create a cinc-install.sh by pulling down https://omnitruck.cinc.sh/install.sh

I'd prefer to keep this with using the install.sh if possible. Can you just download https://omnitruck.cinc.sh/install.sh and replace it with what we have in openstack-chef and change it to '-v 15'?

Any reason why you're doing it this way instead of the other method?

If we're going to be using Cinc, I recommend we install it in a similar fashion we've been doing with Chef using the install.sh script. In order to get it to work with the Cinc omnitruck instance, you'll want to download the script from https://omnitruck.cinc.sh/install.sh and then use that one instead.

Are you just testing or intending to replace entirely? We may want to just create a new install-cinc.sh script instead of replacing this one depending on which.

My idea was to create an ansible role that would install either chef or cinc depending on some variable, similar to e.g. ensure-python in the upstream jobs.

I'll take a look at the install script, though at least for stable branches I'd actually prefer to install a pinned client version, too, instead of "latest 15.x". That avoids regressions that may go unnoticed for some time unless one creates and watches a periodic testing job. It would also be more inline with our real-world deployments, where we don't update the client for the lifetime of a stable branch. (Unless required by some bug, but I don't remember that happen.)

I like the idea of testing both via some variable!

Regarding latest 15.x. From my experience there are very few regressions between the minor releases and if there is one, they usually release a fix quickly to resolve it. I think it's important to test the latest major release no matter what it is so we can catch any issues that may happen.

At any rate, you can still use the script to pin specific versions, i.e. "-v 15.10" or even "-v 15.10.12". For stable branches, it might make sense to pin it at least the minor version since patch version bumps in the stable channel only include critical regression fixes and no feature additions.

However for Workstation, I do think it's important to pin that since they update cookstyle regularly which can result in extra work depending on how things are.

So in short:

1. I recommend we put to just the major version in the master branch
2. Pin to the minor version on the stable branches

Thoughts?

roles/configure-os-mirrors/README.rst.message: Can we safely map these onto one another where known in advance? That might be a nice user friendlyness feature.

I was thinking that originally, or a releases field which includes a list of release codenames for which a given set of packages is suitable (and perhaps a means of wildcarding one for all known releases). Some unofficial package repositories may use debian10 instead of buster, or include versions which are suitable for multiple releases and so wouldn't logically be named in a distro-release-specific way. There's also the common practice of off-label package use, where someone wants to mirror an Ubuntu Bionic PPA but install the packages from it onto a Debian Buster node (or maybe install some official Ubuntu Focal packages onto a Bionic node for that matter in cases where the backports suite isn't providing it), so while there may be *a* release codename in the suite's name, it's not relevant to the node where the entry is getting installed. The source lines basically just describe arbitrary URLs, thus might be named after some version of the software being supplied from it or... any of a myriad of other possibilities really.

As I think about this, I wonder whether we could instead have a placeholder/template variable which gets substituted with the release name? This reduces the complexity of the list significantly, and could still allow literal values if there's no release codename variable in a given suite entry. Something like "{ansible_distribution_release}-security" in the former case or "my-multi-release-packages" in the latter.

Should we match this against a 'release' field in the dictionary instead. Otherwise the role will silently not work if someone wants to add a repository that doesn't follow the convention of including the release in the suite

I guess this is filtering metadata, it wouldn't get incorporated into the resulting sources list for the system. What should be the behavior if this is not provided? Just assuming the entry is valid for any arch in that case would make the most sense, as with a typical multi-architectire mirror you shouldn't have to care.

extra spaces here 

Nov 07 10:53:01 localhost.localdomain dhcp-all-interfaces.sh[852]: /usr/local/sbin/dhcp-all-interfaces.sh: line 151: tries: command not found

IMHO you mix build-time and run-time.

Images might typically build in one environment and build in another one.  Therefore the resulting image should not have any information of the build environment.
This script does not run in the build environment. It's run in the built image by the init system during boot.

I think we may want to use the error codes of rdisc6 here.
If we get a timeout we should probably just move on, if we get an error we should do seme retries to wait for the local-link-addr? to be available.

From RDISC6(8) manual page:
If  rdisc6  does  not  receive any response after the specified number of attempts waiting for wait_ms milliseconds each time, it will exit with code 2. On error, it exits with code 1.  Otherwise it exits with code 0.
Looking at the error codes wouldn't be a bad idea I can't say what the error code was in my example, I guess it was exit 1 as it didn't wait for a response.

I think we should insert a short sleep here, I seen this loop complete 3 times without getting anything from rdisc6 (it doesn't seem to be waiting), when I add a sleep it worked.

> Nov 07 12:32:51 localhost.localdomain dhcp-all-interfaces.sh[860]: ++ rdisc6 --single eth0
> Nov 07 12:32:51 localhost.localdomain dhcp-all-interfaces.sh[860]: + RA='Soliciting ff02::2 (ff02::2) on eth0...'
> Nov 07 12:32:51 localhost.localdomain dhcp-all-interfaces.sh[860]: + '[' False == True ']'

It seems I am having an egg/chick issue here, for the dnsmasq, if enable-ra is not configured, the rdisc6 will get nothing from it, but if configured, dnsmasq would refuse to offer an address (maybe is because of the iaid changed) on the second run, unless the previous lease is expired.

This breaks building IPA with CentOS 8: https://e6e79a4a5a78bf536503-240d4aa44573f96d2050363ab0d496a6.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/696383/1/check/ironic-python-agent-check-image-dib-centos8/d9075f3/job-output.txt

Right it was added to RDO (https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/q/topic:ndisc6+(status:open+OR+status:merged), and downstream RHEL8 have it ndisc6-1.0.3-9.el8ost. 

The actual script is designed to test for the existance of the ndicsc utilities before trying to use them. The package is installed with:

dnf and yum behaves different for missing packages, I believe yum would exit OK but print a message that the missing package was not installed by default. dnf will exit with an error if packages are missing.

doc/source/developer_resources/backup_re.message: any known issue or limitation in current solution?

Two comes to mind:
- Ceph application data is not backed up. It is preserved at restore when wipe_ceph_osds=false but not restored when wipe_ceph_osds=true. So, if needed, users should protect against Ceph clusters failures through off-box custom backups.
- Users should make sure that, for any custom Kubernetes PODs not integrated with stx that uses the local registry the correct images are present after restore so that these apps are able to restart automatically.
Note that for stx integrated application the images are downloaded automatically from external sources to the local registry on restore.

Given the fact that we are working on making the ETCD database restore mandatory for all cases, the 3 options become two: Platform restore and OpenStack application backup and restore.

When restoring the platform user can then chose if it wants to keep the ceph cluster (wipe_ceph_osds=false - the default) or wipe it and restore ceph data from off-box copies.

# DOCKER PROXIES
# ==============
#
# If the host OAM network is behind a proxy, Docker must be configured with
# the same proxy. When an http and/or https proxy is provided, a no-proxy
# address list can optionally be provided. This list will be added to the
# default no-proxy list derived from localhost, loopback, management and oam
# floating addresses at run time. Each address in the list must neither
# contain a wildcard nor have subnet format.

# docker_http_proxy: http://proxy.com:1234
# docker_https_proxy: https://proxy.com:1234
# docker_no_proxy:
#   - 1.2.3.4
#   - 5.6.7.8

I'd recommend you to follow the py2 convention defined in the PEP here https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/#suggested-syntax-for-python-2-7-and-straddling-code

For other reviewers, we discussed this on IRC. To summarize, I think this is acceptable. Attempting to backport this to stable/train or earlier will cause the Python 2.7 jobs to fail due to invalid syntax (SyntaxError). This is no different to f-strings, kw-only args or any other Python 3.x-only syntax and should be pretty obvious to the reviewer.

It's also reasonable to include this change here. I'm changing the function signature so this is a related change. If I were not changing the signature, then I would agree that this should be done separately, yes.

OK, after discussing on IRC, I'm OK with approving this change as of now, provided people wanting to review this change WOULD READ MY COMMENT AND UNDERSTAND THAT THIS COULDN'T WORK WITH STABLE/STEIN AND STABLE/TRAIN.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Add support to specify multiple values for filter options

Previously, if user passes recovery_method query parameter as auto,reserved_host as shown in the below url:

  http://<IP address>/instance-ha/v1/5822950ca0fe4399886e695c26dae6c1/segments?
recovery_method=auto%2Creserved_host

Then, it wasn't returning failover segments with recovery method auto and reserved_host. It was treating `auto,reserved_host` as one recovery method.

This patch allows user to pass multiple values in recovery_method query parameter with a ',' as delimiter.

For e.g.
If user wants to search for failover segments with recovery methods auto and reserved_host, it can be passed in recovery_method query parameter as `auto,reserved_host`.

No need to mention this dependency as it's not required.

To make the distinction between the two patterns intuitive, I optimized their respective error code and made it easier to add new asynchronous errors code about subsequent features.

In general, I don't see a problem with re-doing the error and action codes in this file; but, it has no direct relationship with the bug you're trying to fix. Can you please consider splitting this into two changes:

1) Re-assigning the numbers for Actions, errors and filters
   - Make sure to add an "upgrade" note

    We must also make it clear *why* these numbers are
 changing - the error codes itself have not a lot of significance,
 and they must be read along with the message that accompanies
 them; however, since we have a numeric ID in the response
 schema for user messages, we'd have to continue to set
 and include it in the API response when a user lists messages. 

2) Fix the missing user message for share extension failures.

Suggest adding the following, to keep with the purpose of this feature:

 "The share status has been set to "extending_error". 
 This action cannot be re-attempted until the status has 
 been rectified. Contact your administrator to determine 
 the cause of this failure."




User messages must let users know what happened, and if possible, what to do - the latter part is important for actions that can be re-attempted by correcting erring request parameters. In this case, no matter what the user attempts, they cannot achieve their goal; so it's good to let them know of that.
yes, it will be more useful for user.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: This change will only work on controller-0. When a second controller is installed, the permissions on the .kube directory will not be modified. This would require an additional change in puppet. For example, see class platform::kubernetes::master::init in kubernetes.pp where we change the permissions on the /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf file.

Note that this file is being extensively changed with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/719970, which is going to be delivered soon. You will have to rebase on top of that change after it merges and recode/retest your fix.

Looking at the second controller, I don't see a /home/sysadmin/.kube directory at all after the initial install. It only gets created after the first kubectl commands is run. So we're probably OK on the second controller.

I am assuming this is the command that creates the /home/sysadmin/.kube directory. In a non-DC system (with a local ansible install) I can see this directory is owned by the sysadmin user. Tee - why is it different for DC systems? Can we specify that the kubectl commands are run by the sysadmin user? That way we wouldn't have to change the permissions after the fact. It seems the issue is that the command is being run as root, but being pointed to /home/sysadmin.

It does not matter what system DC or non-DC, helm init will fail if the task is executed remotely as sysadmin (see comments on lines 182-183). The workaround is to execute the task as root then change .helm directory ownership to sysadmin:sys_protected in subsequent task. Looks like this workaround has to be applied to the .kube directort as well due to the issue described here https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/84169.

The ownership you observed in non-DC system is sysadmin:sys_protected because the controller-0 bootstrap was executed locally.

I assume the /home/sysadmin/.kube directory is being created here because bringup_helm.yml is the first place we run kubectl? That seems a bit fragile as it could change. Can we just create this directory with the right permissions in an earlier playbook - bringup_kubemaster.yml for example? Tee should comment.

Yuxing, can you confirm that this directory is created during the initial "kubectl apply" command? not the initial kubectl command?

Please try to create this directory with the right ownership beforehand and make sure to test both bootstrap replay and remote bootstrap. If it does not work, then combine this task with the one on line 212 using with_items.

ya i can see that argument.

We should really ensure this is stored as a passphrase and not a async key as is currently the case with encrypted volumes. The last time I looked at this it wasn't possible but that may have changed now.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/rbd_pro.message:
If life would be so simple :)

You should:
1. Configure a system with multiple ceph tiers (see below how to configure it). Take into account only the OSDs in the current tier, not all the OSDs in the system, as we have multiple kube-rbd pools, one per storage tier.
2. Take into account that we have replication configured to 2, so you should take into account only the OSDs of a host in a goup as the other one is just a replica.
Example 1, you have 4 storage nodes, each with 1 OSD then you have to multiply only by 2, not by four like this:

Multiply by 2:
==============
pair 1:
 storage-0
   osd.0
 storage-1
   osd.1
pair 2:
 storage-1
   osd.2
 storage-2
   osd.3

Example 2

Multiply by 3:
==============
pair 1:
 storage-0
   osd.0
   osd.4
 storage-1
   osd.1
   osd.5
pair 2:
 storage-1
   osd.2
 storage-2
   osd.3

3. Take into account replication 3... yah, we can isntall 3 storage nodes per group.


Now, the fun part: Two more things you should take into account:
A. What happens if we add the OSDs later on, will the number of PGs for this pool be updated? We may get into the same case if, for example, we initially start with a single OSD so that pg_num will be set to 64 per node but remain contant even though we add OSDs and should dynamically update.
This better be implemented in: /stx/platform-armada-app/stx-platform-helm/stx-platform-helm/helm-charts/ceph-pools-audit/templates/bin/_ceph-pools-audit.sh.tpl
Then, when dynamically increasing PG_NUM, take into account that we can only do this in steps of 64 per OSD. More than this will be denied by ceph.
B. How do we optimise the PG_num as per https://docs.ceph.com/docs/mimic/rados/operations/placement-groups/ and https://ceph.com/pgcalc/


Configuring secondary tier
==========================

source /etc/nova/openrc

echo ">>> Add secondary tier"
set -ex
system storage-tier-add ceph_cluster gold
set +ex

echo ">>> Add secondary tier backend"
set -ex
TIERS=$(system storage-tier-list ceph_cluster)
system storage-backend-add ceph -n gold -t $(echo "$TIERS" | grep gold | awk '{print $2}')
set +ex
while true; do system storage-backend-list | grep " gold " | grep " configured "; if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then break; else sleep 10; fi; done

source /etc/nova/openrc

HOST="storage-0"

echo ">>> Get disk & tier info"
DISKS=$(system host-disk-list ${HOST})
TIERS=$(system storage-tier-list ceph_cluster)
echo "Disks:"
echo "$DISKS"
echo "Tiers:"
echo "$TIERS"
set +ex

echo ">>> Add OSDs to primary tier"
set -ex
system host-stor-add ${HOST} $(echo "$DISKS" | grep /dev/sdb | awk '{print $2}') --tier-uuid $(echo "$TIERS" | grep storage | awk '{print $2}')
set +ex

echo ">>> Add OSDs to secondary tier"
set -ex
system host-stor-add ${HOST} $(echo "$DISKS" | grep /dev/sdc | awk '{print $2}') --tier-uuid $(echo "$TIERS" | grep gold | awk '{print $2}')
set +ex

This comment doesn't quite match the code.  Your new code is ordering the device images across all of the devices so that all root-key images will be written first, then all key-revocation images, then all functional images.

This would work okay for now since we only update one device at a time, but in the longer-term we may want to be able to update multiple devices simultaneously, and in that case we'll want to be able to write a functional image on one device while writing a root-key image on another device.

So at a bare minimum I think we'd want to fix the comment to more accurately reflect what the code is doing, and I think we'd still want a TODO message about ordering the images for each device to handle simultaneous updates of multiple devices.

To answer the question on the other patch about if we should ever cleanup a failed rebuild: absolutely yes. This causes problems for future migrations which get scheduled here.

I also wanted to note, also from the IRC discussion from the other day, if we were to add a destroy_disks_on_failure kwarg to the spawn method, we'd do that only on master as a follow up change and only the task_state-based change would be backported.

As discussed on IRC today, we could use the instance.task_state to know whether we are doing a rebuild and set destroy_disks_on_failure accordingly. It seems to me though, that we shouldn't destroy the disk if rebuild fails, shared or not. If rebuild didn't complete, shouldn't the disk remain?

_create_and_inject_local_root() doesn't actually need the previous value of "created_disks" so I think it'd be cleaner if we didn't pass it in.  Instead, we could handle the logic here:

tmp_created_disks = self._create_and_inject_local_root(....)
created_disks = created_disks or tmp_created_disks

It's actually a small optimisation to pass created_disks here, because we stop checking for disk existence after we found the first created disk. While the cost of disk.exists() isn't high, it's also not free so I erred on the side of not doing it when we already know what we're going to return.

Specifically, if an image defined kernel or ramdisk, and we created them, by passing created_disk here we can void the subsequent redundant exists() check for the root disk.

The other reason to do it is consistency. We do it everywhere else, so we do it here.

_create_domain_and_network previously had only 1 caller which set destroy_disks_on_failure=True: spawn. That's the subject of this fix.

Everything else previous got destroy_disks_on_failure=False, which now becomes cleanup_on_failure=None. As we pass this directly to _cleanup, this would previously have been cleanup(destroy_disks=False, migrate_data=None), which we now causes us to delete nothing (instance dir or disks).

nova/compute/manager.py.message: do we want to catch the exception here? that is, if it raises exception.InvalidVolume do we want to continue?
No we don't want to continue.
in case exception occurs, should we catch and handle it ?

I know it might be agreessive, but if we make the instance into ERROR only because it's not able to detach the volume...
by function _error_out_instance_on_exception :)
I was thinking that if this fails, the whole operation fails, any suggestion ?

It requires the additional cinder request (to get the volume) but does nothing special: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/volume/cinder.py#L313-L317

begin_detaching does more precise check: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/540bba7f8e049e0eea304ec21ed2da2d03319125/cinder/volume/api.py#L598-L599

So i think you could call only begin_detaching

Ah, you want to prevent error state of the instance if a volume is not attached...

I think you could split this loop onto two ones: the first loop is outside of driver.rebuild, run as a preparation step for it, calls begin_detaching, handles corresponding cinder errors, and rollback detaching state on them. And the second loop stays in this callback function and only detaches volumes.

Thanks for your review and sorry for response so late, we were have a holiday. I agree with you with the first one, the exception is thrown so that we don't set the VM to error, and I don't want to add an new exception just for this, any suggestions?

I forgot some important things.

1 Since an instance can have more than one volume attached, you cannot just fail rollback operation on ckeck_detach (or begin_detaching). Because the fault may occure on the second (or more) volume, when the first volume is already detached. In this case the instance is broken, and we should not keep it that. So the splitting the loop looks appropriate to a preliminary check and safetely marking volumes as detaching.

2 About the exception. If you place the first loop in rebuild_instance (not in _rebuild_instance), you'll do not need to workaround _error_out_instance_on_exception behavior. Otherwise i think you need to raise a special exception, not NotImplementedError. And in both cases you should choose an exception which has to be raised from rebuild_instance as a whole method to an end user.
Thanks a lot, those are really good suggestions!
Thanks
Probably i miss something, but what is a reasion to throw this exception here?
I think you should rollback detaching on error to keep the instance in workable state
Thanks, updated.
Are you sure that it's needed? Why?
having checked again, the vm_state and task state didn't change, so this is not needed, thank you.
fyi: this decoration reverts instance task

If the second volume fails to be begin-detaching, you don't rollback detaching of the first volume.

So that you should use try..except parenthesis outside of the loop.

To rollback detaching you should also distinguish what volumes you've began detaching, and what haven't.
Done. And I think we don't have to distinguish it from here, as the roll_detaching will check the status.
Probably this loop should be placed under 'with' statement below.
Done

BTW, here and below some preliminary checks are performed, which can raise errors. This makes the instance into error state. Looks like this operation doesn't adopt to keep the instance in a good state on any error (i.e. invalid image specified). So that i wondered why jichenjc	asked on PS3 to handle exceptions on detach preparation steps.

please add instance=instance here
the changes here and below are unrelated to this patch set. please consider splitting them out to an additional one
The identation, please/
Probably we need a test on this

If one of roll_detaching operations fails, this message will be omitted. Could you put it before the loop above?

Other question is - is logged info sufficient for admin to understand what volume couldn't be detached?
Are you sure this improves code appearance?

I'm wondering why you don't have a try block inside the for loop above and only roll the begin_detach that failed, rather than roll them all.  I don't know if there will be unintended consequences happening if attempting to roll a detach that you didn't attempt to detach in the first place.

Hi, thanks for your review, if one of the volume call begin_detach and failed, we have to roll all the volume that has already successfully called begin_detach, as in:
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/cinder/tree/cinder/volume/api.py#n610

neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/.message: pep8: F401 'sqlalchemy as sa' imported but unused

It's baffling that we don't know how to reproduce the problem.

Still if we assume there are systems out there with vlan_id=0 records when they upgrade this will fail. Shouldn't we delete the vlan_id=0 record and then install the new constraint? This delete should be safe, shouldn't it?
Another technical option may be to add a pre-upgrade check for the vlan_id=0 record. That would give a chance to the administrator to handle it manually.

I agree. Since that situation (vlan_id out of valid interval) is an unstable condition, the administrator should solve manually this issue in the DB (by deleting the invalid registers).

Once the DB is healed, we can apply safely this patch.
Please, I would like more feedback on Bence's comment because this is important. Thanks Bence.

That's the point: a customer found this error in normal operation. Every time you modify the segment range allocations (with VLAN driver, this is the bug case), you'll sync the all of them. That means you'll retrieve all VLAN allocations. When this happens, the OVO will fail because vlan_id=0 (or >MAX_VLAN_TAG) is not a valid number. 

If there is an invalid VLAN tag in the DB, should we delete it by default? This problem should be solved manually by the administrator, IMO.
how this constraint will work if there will be already in DB ID outside of this new range? Will it pass or fail to upgrade db? I don't have env now to test that so that's why I'm asking :)
I don't think that migration will fail, as I understand this will be evaluated when we set/update data, also this will work from certain mysql version.

Out of curiousity I wanted to test if the upgrade fails or not, but I couldn't really.

The reason is that MySQL until version 8.0.16 does not support CHECK CONSTRAINTS, instead it silently ignores them:

https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/check-constraints-table.html

Also mentioned in sqlalchemy documentation:

https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/core/constraints.html#check-constraint

My ubuntu 18.04 based devstack has way older mysql (5.7.26).

All this may be worth a comment here.

Plus I think this also means that we could end up with two different actual db schemas based on the underlying mysql version when the upgrade is performed.

As recommended by Bence, I added an upgrade check [1] to ensure that this situation is not happening during the DB migration. BTW, having a vlan allocation "out of bonds" should never happen and if happens, should be solved manually by the administrator.


[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/717083/5/neutron/cmd/upgrade_checks/checks.py

As you mention, MySQL 8.0.16 [1] is the first version supporting check constrains and this version is quite recent (from 2018). Other DB started supporting this feature in the last years:
- https://mariadb.com/kb/en/constraint/#check-constraints (version 10.2.1, 2016).
- https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/ddl-constraints.html (version 9.4, 2014).

The point is:
- Those versions not supporting this feature will ignore it. This upgrade will always work.
- You will have a different schema depending on the DB engine, but once you update the engine, you can always perform a full DB migration. In any case, this difference won't affect you. The VLAN limitation is enforced in the code; this DB engine enforcement is just an extra check.
- In new deployments, this check will be present.


I'll add a comment here.

[1]https://dev.mysql.com/doc/relnotes/mysql/8.0/en/news-8-0-16.html
